questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not included in the secondary level of the healthcare system?
questions.explanation:
Medical colleges are included in the tertiary level of the health care system, which is also the 
second referral centre.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not an element of primary healthcare?
questions.explanation:
748 
Sold by @itachibot Providing physical rehabilitation is not an element of primary health care. Primary health centers 
(PHCs) are only responsible for the popularization and mainstreaming of PMR in the community. Primary health care refers to essential health care made universally available to individuals and 
acceptable to them, through their full participation and at a cost the community and country can 
afford.

questions.question: Question 3: All of the following are pillars of primary health care except:
questions.explanation: Health education is an element of primary health care, not a pillar.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statement is false regarding ASHA workers?

options.a: Few of their responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers
options.b: They should have formal education at least up to class 10
options.c: A population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA
options.d: They have to procure ORS, OCPs, IFA tablets from CHC

questions.explanation:
Accredited social health activist (ASHA) workers do not need to procure supplies from CHCs. 
They only act as depot holders for certain essential supplies so that they are readily available to 
their community. These essential supplies may include ORS, contraceptives, iron-folic acid tablets, chloroquine, 
disposable delivery kits, oral contraceptive pills, condoms, etc.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Anganwadi workers?

options.a: One AWW serves a population of 5000
options.b: They are appointed under the ICDS scheme
options.c: They link the community with the health services
options.d: Their responsibilities include counsel for immunization, health education, and nutrition

questions.explanation:
The norm is one Anganwadi worker (AWW) per 400-800 population. Anganwadi workers (AWW) are allotted under the integrated child development services (ICDS). 
AWW are selected from the community they are to serve and act as links between the community 
and health services. They are mostly part-time workers. Responsibilities of an AWW include: • Health checkups and growth chart maintenance • Counsel women on birth preparedness, importance of safe delivery, immunization and 
contraception and prevention of common infections including STD and RTIs. • Nutrition • Health education • Non-formal school education • Referral services

questions.question: Question 6: One male health assistant is posted for a population of:
questions.explanation:
One male and female health assistant are required for a population of 30,000 in plain areas and 
of 20,000 in hilly or remote areas. 749 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: How many people does a Mahila Arogya Samiti member cater to?
questions.explanation:
1 Mahila Arogya Samiti member is appointed for a population of 250-500 (covering about 50-100 
households).

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following duties would be performed by a male health worker?
questions.explanation:
The duties of a male health worker include chlorination of water bodies, distribution of 
conventional contraceptives, and reproductive and child health services. Maintanence of eligible couple registers (part of family planning activities) and immunization are 
duties of female health workers. Health workers (male and female) are 1 per 5000 in plains and 1 per 3000 in remote or hilly 
areas.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not a duty of a female health worker?
questions.explanation:
Malaria surveillance activities, in accordance with the National Vector Borne Disease Control 
Programme, are the duty of a male health worker. Health workers (male and female) are 1 per 5000 in plains and 1 per 3000 in remote or hilly 
areas.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following are not involved in providing antenatal support to pregnant women?
questions.explanation:
Trained birth attendants or dais provide medical services during delivery and in the post-partum 
period. They cater to a population of 1000 in villages. Antenatal support is provided by the following: • Health workers (male and female) - 1 per 5000 in plains and 1 per 3000 in hilly or remote areas. • Health assistants (male and female) - 1 per 30,000 in plains and 1 per 20, 000 in remote or hilly 
areas. • Anganwadi workers - 1 per 400-800 in plains and 1 per 300-800 in hilly or remote areas.

questions.question: Question 11: How many people does one sub-center in a hilly or remote area cater to?
questions.explanation:
A sub-center caters to a population of 5000 in general areas and 3000 in hilly or remote areas. Services provided at sub-centers: 750 
Sold by @itachibot • Maternal and child health, family planning • Counseling for abortion and adolescent health care • Water quality monitoring and sanitation promotion • Assistance to school health services • Field visits and treating minor ailments • Training of ASHA and birth attendants • Disease surveillance and National Health Programme functions

questions.question: Question 13: As a PHC medical officer, you would be responsible for all of the following activities except:

options.c: Formal education of children < 6 years of age
options.d: Collection and recording of vital events

questions.explanation: Formal education is not a function of primary health centers in India.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following category of workers are not part of the workforce at PHCs?
questions.explanation:
751 
Sold by @itachibot A radiographer is not a part of the manpower at a PHC. They are present in CHCs. Accountants cum data entry operators, health educators, and clerks are appointed at PHCs.

questions.question: Question 15: What is the minimum number of beds a HWC-PHC is required to have?
questions.explanation:
The minimum number of beds a HWC-PHC is required to have is 2. Per the IPHS 2022 
guidelines, the desirable number of beds in a HWC-PHC is 4. Note: The desirable beds will be over and above the essential beds.

questions.question: Question 16: One community health center (CHC) covers a population of:
questions.explanation: Each community (CHC) covers a population of 80,000-1,20,000. Services provided by CHC: • Care of routine and emergency cases in medicine and surgery • Maternal, newborn, and child health • Family planning • All the functions of national health programmes • Physical medicine and rehabilitation • Oral health • School and adolescent health services • Blood storage facility • Diagnostic services • Referral services • Maternal death review (MDR)

questions.question:
Question 19: Under the National Health Mission, an urban CHC for a metropolitan city caters to a 
population of how many persons?
questions.explanation: An urban CHC caters to a population of 5 lakh in a metropolitan city and 2.5 lakh in other cities. An urban PHC caters to a population of 50,000.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the staffing at urban primary health centers?
questions.explanation:
An urban primary health center will cover 50,000-60,000 population and will be staffed with: • Two doctors (one regular and one on a part-time basis) • 3 staff nurses • 1 pharmacist • 1 lab technician • 1 lady health visitor • 4–5 ANMs (depending upon the population covered) • Other clerical and support staff and one program manager Basic functions provided are: • OPD • Basic lab diagnosis • Drug/contraceptive dispensing • Health education along with referral services *Note: The above data is according to IPHS 2017 guidelines. The revised guidelines as per IPHS 
2022 have been listed in the pearl attached below. 754

questions.question:
Question 21: 746 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is the principal unit of administration in India?
questions.explanation:
The principal unit of administration in India is the district under a collector. Under districts are the sub-divisions, tahsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, 
panchayats, etc. As of 2021, there are 748 districts in India.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
questions.explanation:
The Panchayat Samiti or Janpada Panchayat operates at the block level. Panchayati Raj is a three-tier structure of rural self-government in India. It operates at the 
following levels: • Panchayat at the village level (includes Gram Sabha, Gram Panchayat, and Nyaya Panchayat) • Panchayat Samiti or Janpada Panchayat at the block level • Zilla Parishad at the district level

questions.question: Question 23: Community or village health guides are selected by:
questions.explanation:
Village health guides (VHGs) are selected by the medical officer-in-charge (MO). 2-3 candidates are put forward by the community for the position of a VHG. The MO selects one 
of them after consultation with the block development officer and field staff.

questions.question:
Question 24: As a PHC medical officer, you would keep all of the following in mind while selecting a village 
health guide except:
questions.explanation:
Village health guides (VHG) are chosen by the medical officer-in-charge (including PHC MO). Age 
is not a criterion for selection. The VHG scheme was introduced in 1977. Guidelines for choosing a VHG include: • They can be of either sex but must be residents of the village • They must know to read and write and have education up to 6th grade • They must be able to spare around 2-3 hours a day for community work • They must be acceptable to all parts of the community VHGs are trained for 2-3 months before beginning work. The norm is to have 1 VHG per 1000 
population. 755
